Think high school musicals are all about Zac Efron and silly love songs?
Think again.
Students at Lexington High School in Massachusetts have written an original play about the Holocaust and the power of imagination.
Now, the roots of this play come from an underground arc-rock(ph) album released when some of these students were in kindergarten.
Another inspiration: a punk princess who's a Lexington High alum.
Avishay Artsy of New Hampshire Public Radio looked into this strange and fantastical project, and he began with a rehearsal.
(SOUNDBITE OF PLAY REHEARSAL)
All right, let's start from the top.
We'll walk through it with the music, and we'll make the adjustments as we go along.
The scene is a restaurant.
Anne Frank sits at a table.
(SOUNDBITE OF PLAY REHEARSAL)
(As Anne Frank) We have duck a l'orange, saffron couscous and steak, or would you like to have some of our fine wines?
Helga, darling?
Please?
Answer me?
This is all in Anne's imagination.
In fact, she's in a death camp, dying of typhus and losing her grasp on reality.
Emma Feinberg plays Anne Frank.
She's a freshman at Lexington High School, and the play the school is presenting is called ""With the Needle That Sings in Her Heart."" It's about Frank's final months at Bergen-Belsen.
Faced with horror and brutality, she escapes into a world where prisoners and Nazi officers become circus performers.
Unidentified Woman #1: Anne looks to the dead, walking onto a platform.
The ringmaster appears and gestures up.
Tightrope Anne(ph) comes down from the room.
She walks to Anne; they face each other.

If this sounds a little out there for a high school play, consider the source material: The album ""In the Aeroplane Over the Sea,"" released in 1998 by a then-little-known band called Neutral Milk Hotel.
The group was part of a collective of musicians living in Athens, Georgia.
Strange, dreamlike lyrics reference a two-headed boy, the king of carrot flowers and Anne Frank, though never by name.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""OH, COMELY"")
(Singing) I know they buried her body with others, her sister and mother and five hundred families.
And will she remember me, fifty years later?
I wish I could save her in some sort of time machine.
Know all your enemies.

The achingly, childlike lyrics, the intensity and purity and urgency of the vocals, the use of horns, organs, banjo and singing saw startled listeners a decade ago, and soon earned the album an obsessive following, including Amanda Palmer.
The 33-year-old musician calls it the ""Sgt.
Pepper's"" of her generation.
I watch people proselytize this record all over the world.
It's like this secret brotherhood of awesome music that's never had any kind of big mainstream publicity.
It's just this sacred record that people connect through.
Palmer's a Lexington High alum and acted in several plays under the guidance of theater director Steven Bogart.
He's been leading drama workshops at the school for nearly two decades.
Palmer went on to form The Dresden Dolls - a band she describes as Brechtian punk cabaret.
The duo has released a handful of records and toured the globe, but Palmer always stayed in close contact with her old mentor.
After the band became successful, and I started going out into the world and delving into different theatrical projects, I missed this environment.
I missed the purity of the process.
She proposed to Bogart that they work with his students to write a play inspired by ""In the Aeroplane Over the Sea,"" but most of his students had never heard of it, like sophomore Lindsay Kosos.
I was sort of taken aback by how open it was and sort of thrown off, but I kept listening to it and found I just couldn't stop.
And it's so beautiful because every time you listen to this music, you hear something different, and I listen to it all the time.
I, like, fall asleep listening to it.
(Soundbite of song ""The Kind of Carrot Flowers Pt.
(Singing) When you were young, you were the king of carrot flowers and how you built the towers tumbling through the trees.
In holy rattlesnakes that fell all around your feet.
The students spend several weeks with the music, creating sculptures and drawings inspired by the lyrics, and then began improvising scenes.
(Singing) Your mom would drink until she was no longer speaking, and dad will dream of all the different ways to die.
Senior Roy Barron(ph).
We never sat down and talked about, you know, oh, this song, he's trying to say this.
This song, he's meaning this.
You couldn't write an essay explaining these are the motifs, these are the metaphors he's using.
It's just, you feel it.
You can't speak it.
In the Aeroplane Over the Sea"" was the band's last recording.
Sales have remained consistent in the years since, and its members went on to form other bands.
But Neutral Milk Hotel singer and songwriter, Jeff Mangum, stopped releasing music.
Jeff Mangum is somebody who was on a personal quest, and he still is.
That's Robert Schneider, front man for the band Apples in Stereo.
He produced ""In the Aeroplane Over the Sea"" and played on some of the tracks.
Schneider says he's thrilled that high school kids have turned the album into a play.
It reminds me of me and Jeff and our friends when we were that age, and we were doing these bizarre creative sorts of things.

That's exactly what they're doing, and what we were doing was paying homage to the people that we loved and that moved us, completely without reference to the music that probably most of our peers loved.

Well because his relationship with the team had developed into a soap opera.
The Broncos owner, Pat Bowlen, had fired the long-time head coach there, Mike Shanahan, back in December after a third mediocre season in a row.
And the new coach is a guy named Josh McDaniels who came from the successful New England Patriots organization.

Now, McDaniels listened to a trade offer for Cutler, as he should have, but the quarterback and his agent - who, by the way, is the agent that orchestrated Brett Favre's drama in leaving Green Bay last year.
These guys were apparently miffed by the conversations about the trade and by some inelegant spin about what went down.
And it reached a point where Cutler told the team he wanted out, and the owner Pat Bowlen called this bluff.
Now this sounds like a classic power struggle, a talented athlete, a high powered agent, a prominent team.
Isn't this a big risk, though, for Denver Broncos, if you look at them just as a business?
Well, it is.
They've alienated a lot of fans who were enamored of a player who has perceived as the team's savior, the guy that would lead him back to the Super Bowl.

On the other hand, teams do what they think gives them the best chance to win, and I think the owner and the new coach analyzed the player, Jay Cutler, and they had questions about this kid's maturity, his personality, his leaderships skills, his compatibility with what the new coach had planned tactically for the team, what he might expect in a new contract.
And in a talk radio sense, yeah, that's risky.
You don't trade away the statistics.
In a business sense, though, it seems downright progressive what the Broncos did.

They may not have planned on it, but I think they struck a blow for rational thinking in pro sports and they got three high draft picks and a quarterback, Kyle Orton, in return from the Chicago Bears.
That's a lot.
